Award.AwardTitle: The California-Arizona Minority Partnership for Astronomy Research and Education (CAMPARE)
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is to support the California-Arizona Minority Partnership for Astronomy Research and Education (CAMPARE) program, led by Cal Poly Pomona, for their student internship program in the Summer of 2014. CAMPARE is designed to advance undergraduate Astronomy research and education among Hispanic and other minority students, in order to promote their participation and advancement in Astronomy and closely related fields, and increase their numbers in Ph.D. programs in those fields. Undergraduate students from their home institutions (mainly in the Cal Poly system) spend a summer working at one of four research sites (University of Arizona Steward Observatory, SETI Institute, JPL, and Caltech) on research in Astronomy, Planetary Science, Space Science, or Astrobiology. Through robust mentoring and support, the program aims to significantly enhance the recruitment and retention of students from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The California-Arizona Minority Partnership for Astronomy Research and Education (CAMPARE) is a summer research program with the mission to advance undergraduate astronomy research and education among traditionally underrepresented groups (including women and Hispanic students) in order to promote their participation and advancement and increase their numbers in PhD programs in astronomy and related fields. CAMPARE participants are designated "CAMPARE Scholars".

CAMPARE scholars are selected from a network of 22 California State University (CSU) campuses and California Community Colleges (CCC) spend 10 weeks as research interns at one of eleven major research institutions in California, Arizona, or Wyoming (Univ. of Arizona Steward Observatory, the SETI Institute, Northern Arizona Univ., Univ. of Wyoming, JPL/Caltech, the Carnegie Observatories, and six UC campuses, UCLA, UC Irvine, UC Riverside, UC San Diego, UC Santa Barbara, and UC Berkeley). The network is shown in Figure 1.

Almost all of the CSU and CCC campuses in the network are Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs), and of the 62 students who have participated in the past 6 years, 28 are women and 34 are men; 29 are Hispanic, 4 are African American, and 3 are Native American or Pacific Islander, including 7 female Hispanic, 2 female African-American, and 1 female Pacific Islander participants. Overall, more than 85% of participants are URM, female, or both. The demographics and growth of the program in its first 6 years are shown in Figure 2.

The graduation rate among CAMPARE scholars is 97%, and of the 37 CAMPARE scholars who have graduated with a Bachelor’s degree, 21 have completed or are pursuing graduate education in astronomy or a related field, at institutions including UCLA, USC, UC Riverside, Stanford, Univ. of Rochester, Georgia Tech, Kent State, Indiana Univ., Univ. of Oregon, Syracuse, and the Fisk-Vanderbilt Master’s-to-PhD program.

The CAMPARE graduation rate is twice the national average for STEM majors, the percent pursuing some form of graduate degree is three times the national average, and the percent enrolled in PhD programs is 20 times the national average for URM students. Including 8 students who are currently working but who have indicated they plan to apply to graduate school, 78% (29) of CAMPARE graduates are pursuing or plan to pursue graduate education, an extraordinary percentage for a program with such a large percentage of underrepresented students. Most of the remaining students are working in STEM jobs in industry or government, or training to become high school teachers. This breadth of outcomes is itself a success of the program, particularly the students training to teach high school physics. These future teachers will have a large impact on their fields through their teaching careers.

Twenty CAMPARE Scholars have presented their research at a January AAS meeting, and another 8 have presented at another national meeting (DPS, AGU, LPSC, AbSciCon, Mars Conference), following their summer research experience. The students mentioned these opportunities as a program highlight in their evaluations, and a critical experience motivating them to persist and apply to graduate school.

In the National Academy of Sciences 2010 Decadal Survey of Astronomy, “New Worlds, New Horizons in Astronomy and Astrophysics,” the authors noted that, while Blacks, Hispanics, and Native Americans constitute 27 percent of the U.S. population, they account for less than 4 percent of physics and astronomy PhDs awarded in the United States and only 3 percent of faculty members. Women are similarly underrepresented in PhDs earned (20% in physics, 40% in astronomy) and faculty positions held (14% in physics, 17% in astronomy).
